posts.post: Users were able to add descriptions to questions. On December 8, 2015, these were limited to 800 characters, and questions themselves to 150, not affecting existing questions.[26] On August 3, 2017, question details were discontinued entirely and replaced with an optional source URL input field to provide context, reportedly to encourage users to phrase questions more descriptively. Existing question details were stored in comments under respective questions.[27]

posts.post: the same level of mainstream cultural dominance as sites like Twitter, which, at the time, had roughly 326 million registered users.[3][38] This may have been because a large number of registered users on the site did not use it regularly and many did not even know they had accounts since they had either created them unknowingly through other social media sites linked to Quora or created them years previously and forgotten about them
